content: The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include State Grants for Drug and Violence Prevention Programs. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" allocates funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Indian youth programs, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are determined based on specific ratios. The "Drug-Free Schools Reform Act of 1996" allocates funds for grants to Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Indian youth programs, national impact evaluation, and programs for Native Hawaiians. State allotments are determined based on specific ratios, with a minimum allocation requirement to ensure fair distribution among states. The Secretary may reallot funds if a state cannot utilize them within two years. The Secretary may reallot funds to a State if it cannot be used within two years. States are defined as the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Local educational agencies include educational service agencies and consortia. SEC. 4112. STATE APPLICATIONS. State applications for receiving funds under section 4111 must include coordination plans with relevant programs, results of needs assessments for drug and violence prevention, cooperation with national impact evaluations, and any additional information required by the Secretary. The applications will be reviewed using a peer review process. State programs under SEC. 4113 must include coordination plans, needs assessments for drug and violence prevention, cooperation with national impact evaluations, and additional information as required by the Secretary. The chief executive officer of a State must use allocated funds for drug and violence prevention programs. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the total amount received. Grants and contracts are exclusively for prevention or education programs focused on the dangers of illegal drug use and underage drinking. Funds must be used solely for a 'no use,' 'right-wrong' antidrug message. The allocated funds must be used solely for drug and violence prevention programs, with penalties for any misapplication of funds. Grants and contracts must focus on anti-drug messages, and a peer review process is required for awarded grants. The chief executive officer of a State can directly carry out activities or use grants for law enforcement education partnerships. The chief executive officer of a State can carry out drug abuse and violence prevention activities directly or through grants. Funds can be used to award grants to law enforcement agencies for programs like Drug Abuse Resistance Education and Project Legal Lives, emphasizing resistance to substance use and interactive learning about the legal system. The prevention activities include resisting pressures to experiment with substances, interactive legal education through programs like Project Legal Lives, partnerships between law enforcement and child guidance professionals, and before- and after-school activities. "SEC. 4114. EVALUATION AND REPORTING." The Secretary conducts a biennial evaluation of national impact of programs combating violence in schools, collecting data on violence frequency and seriousness in elementary and secondary schools. A report with recommendations is submitted to the President and Congress. The Secretary collects data on violence in schools and submits a report to Congress with recommendations. States must submit reports on their programs under section 4113 every three years, including data on drug use and violence by youth. The Secretary shall provide grants to organizations serving Native Hawaiians to administer programs for their benefit. Native Hawaiian is defined as individuals with ancestors native to Hawaii before 1778.
